children.name: to come from a town, country, etc
come from a1
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive/verb phrase not in progressive]
children.definition: come from/be from/ˈkʌm frɒm, biː ˈfrɒm/  if you come from or are from a particular place, that is where you were born or where you lived for a long time :
examples: đến từ
▪ she comes from japan.
cô ấy đến từ nhật bản
▪ where are you from?
anh đến từ đâu?
▪ my wife’s parents and my parents come from the same town.
bố mẹ của vợ tôi và bố mẹ tôi đến từ cùng quê

children.name: be a native of x
children.definition: be a native ofbe a native of tokyo/london/wales etcto have been born in and to have spent the early part of your life in that place- used especially when you are writing about sb’s life:là công dân
examples: hughes, who is a native of belfast, often uses the city as a setting for his novels.
deparle is a native of rockwood, tennessee.

children.name: be vietnamese by birth b2
children.definition: be american/french/japanese etc by birth to have been born in a particular country or to be a citizen of that country because your parents come from there, especially when you now live somewhere else: là người gốc việt ( sinh ra ở đó nhưng sống ở một nơi khác )
examples: ▪ she’s lived in australia for a long time, but she’s welsh by birth.
▪ they’re russian by birth but they’ve lived in america for so long that they feel little attachment to their homeland.

children.name: be of vietnamese ancestry x
children.definition: be of scottish/russian etc ancestry if you are of scottish/russian etc ancestry, relatives of yours that are now dead came from that country a long time ago:
examples: có nguồn gốc, dòng dõi, tổ tiên là người việt
▪ there are roughly 40 million americans of irish ancestry.
▪ her fine features suggested she was of arabic or indian ancestry.

children.name: to come from a town, country, etc
children.definition: come from a1
examples: be a native of x
be vietnamese by birth b2
be of vietnamese ancestry x

children.name: origin c1
children.definition: origin where a person was born:
examples: he is of north african origin.
of french/german/asian etc origin
two thirds of the pupils are of asian origin.
ethnic origin
the form asks for information about the person’sethnic origin.
country of origin
immigrants rarely return to theircountry of origin.
what is your country of origin?

children.name: hometown x
children.definition: home town/ˌhəʊm ˈtaʊn/  the town where you live now, where you were born, or where you spent most of your early life: quê hương ( nơi bạn sinh ra hay sống đều được )
examples: ▪ i haven’t been back to my home town since my mother died.
▪ she hated her home town so much she would never admit where she was from.

children.name: birthplace x
children.definition: birthplace/ˈbɜːʳθpleɪs/  the place where someone, especially someone famous, was born: nơi sinh, sinh quán ( đặc biệt khi nói về người nổi tiếng )
examples: ▪ we visited the birthplace of lenin in ulyanovsk.
▪ muslims are expected to make at least one pilgrimage to mecca, muhammad’s birthplace.

children.name: place of birth
children.definition: /ˌpleɪs əv ˈbɜːʳθ/  the place where you were born -- used especially inofficialdocuments:
examples: nơi sinh, nguyên quán
▪ forms usually ask you your name, address, nationality and place of birth.
▪ she hoped that one day she would return to her place of birth.

children.name: home a1
children.definition: home the place where you usually live or the place that you come from, especially when that is the place where you feel you belong and where you would most like to live : quê hương ( nơi sinh hay sống mà bạn muốn sống nhất )
examples: ▪ it took us about ten years to think of atlanta as home.
▪ her home, she said, was in southern china, but she hadn’t been there since she was a child.

children.name: to come from a family, social group
come from a1
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive/verb phrase not in progressive]
children.definition: come from / be fromxuất thân từ
examples: ▪ most of the people here come from very poor families.
▪ she comes from a family of seven kids.
▪ he’s from a very upper class background.

children.name: be descended from c2
children.definition: be descended from/biː dɪˈsendd frɒm/  if you are descended from someone, especially someonefamousor a group of people wholived a long time ago,you are related to them:
examples: có nguồn gốc từ ( một người nổi tiếng, hay một nhóm người trong quá khứ )
▪ she always claimed her family was descended from the ancient kings of egypt.
cô ta luôn nói rằng gia đình của cô ta có nguồn gốc từ một vị vua cổ đại của ai cập
▪ the japanese are thought to be descended from tribes from the north of china.
người ta cho rằng người nhật có nguồn gốc từ một bộ lạc đến từ phía bắc trung quốc

children.name: background b1
children.definition: background the particular type of family or social group that you come from: tầng lớp, nguồn gốc xuất thân
examples: ▪ how quickly kids learn to read will often depend on both their ability and their backgrounds.
▪ sylvie had always expected that she would marry someone of a similar background to herself.
working class/jewish etc background:
▪ gary always tried to hide his working class background.

children.name: origins x
children.definition: origins the social position that you were born into and in which you spent the early part of your life, for example who your parents were or whether they were rich or poor: dòng dõi, nguồn gốc ( mà quãng đầu cuộc đời bạn xuất thân )
examples: ▪ miller questioned her closely, about her present job, her family and her origins.
humble originsa poor social position that someone comes from: dòng dõi nghèo khó
▪ politicians love to talk about their humble origins because they think it will make them popular with voters.

children.name: roots b2
children.definition: roots your connection with a place or group in society because you were born there, or your family used to live there :cội nguồn, dòng dõi
examples: rizzo was a man who never forgot his roots.
beth went to israel in search of her roots.

children.name: the place, situation etc that sth comes from
origin b2
children.definition: origin/origins the place or situation in which something begins to exist :nguồn gốc
examples: origin of
a new theory to explain the origins of the universe
in origin
most coughs are viral in origin.
the word is french in origin.
the traditionhasitsorigins inthe middle ages.
old folk talesof unknown origin
country/place of origin(= where something came from )
all meat should be clearly labelled with its country of origin.
a common origin(= a place or situation in which different things all started to exist )it may be that all life on earth has a common origin.
of recent origin(= having started to exist only a short time ago )this particular theory is of very recent origin.
of unknown origin(= used to say that no one knows where, when, or how something started )an ancient folk tale of unknown origin
of doubtful origin(= unknown and possibly suspicious )the fire was still being treated as of doubtful origin.
sth’s historical/geographical/political etc originsthis type of story has its historical origins in eighteenth century gothic novels.|the geographical origins of the plant
have its origin in something(= begin to exist )the ceremony has its origins in medieval times.

trace its origins to something(= used to say that something can find evidence that it began to exist at a particular time or in a particular place )the roman catholic church traces its origins back to the 4th century.
trace the origin of something(= find where, when etc something began to exist )it’s difficult to trace the origin of some words.
owe its origins to something(= used to explain how something began to exist )a government which owes its origins to revolution

sth’s origins lie in something(= something comes from a particular place or or develops from a particular situation )a grape whose origins lie in northern italy|the technique’s origins lie in the popular arts of the time.
sth’s origins go back to something(= used to say when or how something began )the school’s origins go back to the 12th century.
investigate the origin of something(= try to find out where, when etc something began to exist )researchers investigating the origin of aids
the country/place of origin(= the country or place where something is made or produced )the rugs are somewhat cheaper in their country of origin.

children.name: source b2
children.definition: source nguồn
examples: 1a thing, place, activity etc that you get something from :
they get their money from various sources.
source of
the tank’s losing water, but we can’t find the source of the leak.
beans are a very good source of protein.
for me, music is a great source of enjoyment.
at sourcebritish english:
is your pension taxed at source(= before it is paid to you)?
2the cause of something, especially a problem, or the place where it starts
source of
we’ve found the source of the trouble.
the recent name change has been the source of some confusion.
a good/excellent/rich source(= a source that provides a lot of something )milk is a good source of calcium.
a useful sourcepeople said television was their most useful source of local information.
a major/important sourcethe lead mines were once a major source of employment for the islanders.
a great sourcein times of stress, food can be a great source of comfort.
the main/primary sourceit started as a hobby, but now it is his main source of income.
an alternative sourcethe university is exploring alternative funding sources.
an energy sourcewe hope to see increased usage of renewable energy sources.
a food sourceslugs attack potatoes in late summer, when other food sources are disappearing.
a power source(= something that produces power )first, you need to turn off the power source.
a light source(= something that produces light )the statue is illuminated by a hidden light source.
an unknown sourcethe sound came from an unknown source, far away in the distance.

children.name: cradle x
children.definition: cradle literary
examples: the cradle of democracy/civilization/human society etcthe place or situation in which democracy etc first started:: cái nôi
ancient athens is generally thought of as the cradle of democracy.
baghdad, the cradle of civilization

children.name: birthplace x
children.definition: birthplace the place where something first started to exist: nơi sản sinh ra
examples: the birthplace of sth
new orleans is the birthplace of jazz.
ethiopia, the birthplace of coffee
walden pond has been called the birthplace of modern environmentalism.

children.name: root c1
children.definition: root the most important reason for or cause of sth else happening or existing, especially aproblemor sthbad:nguồn gốc , cội rễ
examples: theroot causesof crime
root of
low taxation of the rich is the root of the economic problems in this country.
a competent mechanic should be able to get to the root ofthe problem
the root of all evil
the love of money isthe root of all evil.
be/lie at the root of sth(= be the cause of something )
allergies are at the root of a lot of health problems.

children.name: to be grown or made in a particular place
come from a1
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive/verb phrase not in progressive]
children.definition: come from/be from/ˈkʌm frɒm, biː ˈfrɒm/  đến từ, có nguồn gốc từ
examples: ▪ try this bread -- it comes from the bakery on central avenue.
▪ u.s. officials say some 60 percent of the heroin on the streets comes from myanmar.
▪ all the medical equipment here is from france.

children.name: be made in a1
children.definition: be made in/biː ˈmeɪd ɪn/  to have been made in a particular country:
examples: được làm ra ở
▪ these shoes were made in italy.
những chiếc giày này được làm ra ở ý
▪ about 57 percent of the cars and trucks sold in colombia are made in colombia.
khoảng 57% xe và xe tải được bán ở colombia là làm ra từ colombia
▪ the label on the bottle said the wine was made in germany.
nhãn dán trên chai cho biết rằng rượu này được làm ra ở đức

children.name: in origin b2
children.definition: origin where an object was made: nguồn gốc, xuất xứ
examples: in origin
the furniture was french in origin.

children.name: when a sound, smell etc comes from swh
come from a1
children.definition: come from/ˈkʌm frɒm/  đến từ
examples: ▪ the wind was coming from the west.
▪ coming from outside in the street was the sound of children playing.
▪ there was an awful smell coming from under the sink.

children.name: emanate from x
children.definition: emanate fromformalto come from somewhere : tỏa ra từ , bốc ra từ, vọng ra từ
examples: ▪ smoke emanated from the kitchen window.
▪ the president argued that accusations emanating from congress were not accurate.
▪ just as the audience grew quiet, the unmistakable ring of a cellular phone emanated from the last row of the theater.

children.name: come from a1
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: come from/ˈkʌm frɒm/  use this to say that something that exists now developed from something else that existed before :
examples: đến từ, có nguồn gốc từ, xuất phát từ, nảy ra từ ( cái gì tồn tại trước đó )
▪ my idea for the film came from an article i read about west virginia coal miners.
▪ the name ‘terrier’ comes from the latin word ‘terra’ meaning the earth.

children.name: be based on b1
children.definition: be based on if a film, story, idea, plan etcis based on something else, that is where its basic ideas or facts come from: được dựa trên
examples: ▪ the film is based on a popular bengali novel.
▪ overtime pay will be based on the number of hours you work each week.
▪ your test questions will be based on the work you have done in the past year.

children.name: go back to x
children.definition: go back to to have developed from something that happened or existed a long time ago : có nguồn gốc từ, bắt nguồn từ ( cái gì tồn tại cách đôi khá lâu )
examples: ▪ many phrases in the language go back to early religious writings.
▪ our friendship goes back to our freshman year in college.
▪ jo just refuses to get into a car -- it all goes back to when she had that accident.

children.name: derive from c1
children.definition: derive from/be derived from/dɪˈraɪv frɒm, biː dɪˈraɪvd frɒm/  to have developed from something else, especially by alongorcomplicatedprocess:
examples: bắt nguồn từ ( qua một quá trình dài phức tạp )
▪ much of the english language is derived from latin and greek.
phần lớn ngôn ngữ anh có nguồn gốc từ tiếng latin và hy lạp
▪ about a quarter of the drugs in prescription medicines today are derived from plants.
khoảng một phần tư trong các loại thuốc theo toa ngày nay được lấy từ thực vật

children.name: grow out of x
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: grow out of/ˈgrəʊ aʊt ɒv/  to develop from sth small or simple by becoming bigger or more complicated: phát triển từ
examples: ▪ socialist ideals grew out of an earlier idea that all men are created equal.
▪ the skill of writing grew out of a wish to put speech into a permanent form.

children.name: originate c2
children.definition: originate/əˈrɪdʒɪneɪt, əˈrɪdʒəneɪt/  to have developed in a particular place or from a particular situation:
examples: có nguồn gốc
▪ how did the tradition of wearing costumes on hallowe'en originate?
những trang phục truyền thống halloween có nguồn gốc như thế nào?
originate in : bắt nguồn ( vào năm nào, ở đâu )
▪ welfare is a program that originated in the 1930s to help widows.
welfare là chương trình có nguồn gốc từ những năm 1930 để giúp những người góa chồng
▪ buddhism originated in india and came to china in the first century a.d.
đạo hồi có nguồn gốc từ ấn độ và đến với trung quốc vào thế kỉ đầu sau công nguyên

children.name: have its origins in b2
children.definition: have its origins in if something has its origins in something that existed a long time ago, that is where it comes from and is the reason for it being as it is: có nguồn gốc từ, bắt nguồn từ
examples: modern medicine often has its origins in ancient ways of doing things.
vaudeville had its origins in french street culture.

children.name: be founded on c2
children.definition: be founded on/biː ˈfaʊndd ɒn/  to have one main idea, belief etc that something else develops from:
examples: được hình thành từ
▪ the constitution in this country is not written. it’s founded on tradition and precedent.
hiến pháp ở nước này không được viết ra. nó được hình thành từ truyền thống và tiền lệ trước đó
▪ white resistance to civil rights was founded on age-old fears of democracy.
sự phản kháng đối với quyền công dân được hình thành dựa trên những lo ngại của đảng dân chủ

children.name: have its roots in c1
children.definition: have its roots in/hæv ɪts ˈruːts ɪn/  if something such as a belief or attitude has its roots in conditions that existed earlier, it developed from them and is still influenced by them: bắt rễ , bắt nguồn từ ( cái gì trước nó và bị ảnh hưởng bởi nó )
examples: ▪ many music historians believe that jazz has its roots in blues music.
▪ economic policy in the us has its roots in the free market system.

children.name: develop from b1
children.definition: develop from/evolve fromc1  to come from an original idea or form and change into sth bigger, more important, or more advanced: phát triển từ/ rút ra từ
examples: ▪ the whole basis of her novel evolved from a chance meeting she had with an old friend.
▪ within years, the site developed from an area of waste ground into a thriving farm.

children.name: source x
children.definition: sourceverb
examples: to get something from a particular place
where possible the produce used in our restaurant issourcedlocally.
a photo sourced
photo sourced from substation.org

children.name: be a recipe for c2
children.definition: be a recipe for
examples: disaster/trouble/success, etc.
to be very likely to become a disaster/success, etc
_all those children unsupervised
sounds to me like a recipe for disaster.
